text: a crane that is partially collapsed this
is at 57th Street and fixed and we have
some pictures just coming into the
newsroom a crane is hanging off the side
of a 300 meter tall building in
Manhattan the luxury apartment block is
currently under construction in the
early afternoon of Monday October 29th a
YouTube video shows superstorm sandy
high winds mangling this 26 thousand
pound construction crane leaving its
boom dangling a thousand feet over a
natural gas main in the center of
Midtown and I saw this picture that no
forget the one that we never wanted to
see with the boom hanging backward I was
leaning toward 8020 of it falling
because as you see things and that's
still windy it's still moving so in my
mind that boom was gonna go and there's
nothing you could do it was a big
concern because it was pretty mangled
and we were all concerned about what
would that do to the rest of the
machinery or if the cables were safe the
cables didn't hold then it would have
gone down and this is all possibilities
that that go through your mind as you're
wondering what the hell is going to
happen next this crisis at one of the
tallest and most luxurious residential
buildings became another symbol of the
city's wounded infrastructure and a
possible disaster for the first time
since the storm the developers the
construction crew and the city officials
involved in the crane collapse shared
the panic-stricken moments to secure the
precarious machinery that was being
tossed around in 80 mile an hour winds
as the fire department blocked off the
streets below and evacuated the area the
first order of business make sure that
the supporting structure or the mast
wasn't in any danger of falling Michael
alotta from the Department of Buildings
and Nick Greco from Linley's the
construction contractor walked up more
than 40 floors of a luxury building to
get a closer look the upper floors were
still under construction with no walls
in the wind was howling now once you get
to the open floors it sounds like you're
in World War 3 absolutely I'd only have
to struggle with the wind you're going
up unfinished stairs to get into the
next level so it got more challenging as
you got closer to that last toy we we
were maybe more focused than scared I
don't want to say we were scared but we
knew we had a job to do if we cracked a
few jokes particularly about how slow
some of us were going up it was nervous
laughter I would say and that was
probably the last time I smiled for
about three straight days we got an

of the boom it was just a mangled thing
I was at OSHA what are we going to do
but the biggest hurdle was the complete
communication blackout caused by the
superstorm everybody's going through a
hurricane their cell phone issues they
were power issues there were internet
issues
no email so it was text messaging and
phone calls as long as whoever you were
calling was it was in a zone where they
had service and and we are all operating
somehow out of the lobby of a building
that doesn't have anything
several days later with the storm moving
away from New York City
a meticulous engineering solution was
designed on Saturday workers began
manually turning the dangling boom
nearly 210 degrees counterclockwise to
the side of the building next they tied
the broken boom with eight steel cables
to the building on three floors phase
two was to quickly stabilizable so at
least you can send workers to continue
the security we've responded to so many
incidents in in my career at least in
the city but this is a very unique
incident while a potentially explosive

say they are serious about preventing
